Tennis elbow (lateral epicondylitis) _1:
Patient Description 1:
A 42-year-old, right-handed, male patient, who works as a construction worker, presented with a persistent dull, aching pain in his right outer elbow (lateral epicondyle) that has been ongoing for the past six weeks, with an intensity rating of 6/10. The pain is exacerbated during gripping and lifting activities at work. He has also noticed a feeling of weakness in the affected elbow, particularly when using tools, and some stiffness during the initial hours of the morning. The patient has a history of regular heavy lifting and repetitive use of his right arm in his occupation. No specific previous treatments have been attempted for these symptoms. The clinical examination reveals tenderness and localized pain over the lateral epicondyle, along with weakened grip strength.
Tennis elbow (lateral epicondylitis) _2:
Patient Description 2:
A 35-year-old, female patient, who is an avid tennis player, presented with a sharp, intermittent pain in her left outer elbow (lateral epicondyle). The pain, rated at 7/10 in intensity, is often experienced during her backhand stroke while playing tennis and has been present for the past two months. She has also noticed a sense of weakness in her left elbow during tennis games. The patient's medical history is unremarkable, with no previous similar symptoms. Physical examination elicits tenderness and localized pain over the lateral epicondyle area, along with mild weakness and stiffness in the outer elbow.
Tennis elbow (lateral epicondylitis) _3:
Patient Description 3:
A 50-year-old, right-handed, male office worker presented with a persistent, nagging pain in his right outer elbow (lateral epicondyle), rated at 5/10 in intensity, which has been ongoing for the past four weeks. The pain is exacerbated during repetitive typing and mouse use at work. The patient also reported a sensation of weakness in his right elbow and occasional stiffness, particularly after prolonged periods of desk work. His medical history is significant for a similar episode in the same elbow two years ago, which was managed with a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) for a few weeks. However, the symptoms resolved completely at that time. On examination, tenderness and localized pain are noted over the lateral epicondyle, along with mild weakness in the outer elbow.
